awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Revisiting the operation of mate acquisition
awd_abstract_narration:
Acquiring mates is one of the most fundamental steps to successfully reproducing in many animals. Individuals vary widely in how many mates they acquire, and as a result, how many offspring they produce. Understanding why such variation exists and how it is linked to traits of he organisms is essential for understanding variation between the sexes, populations, and species. Surprisingly, scientists are often unable to predict the conditions under which strong variation in mate acquisition will exist and which traits improve mate acquisition. This research will theoretically and empirically identify a range of understudied ecological factors that influence mate acquisition, thereby transforming our understanding of how animals successfully reproduce. The principle investigator's proposed educational activities will be integrated seamlessly into the project and facilitate training of diverse K-12 students and teachers, as well as undergraduate and graduate students.

Enhanced understanding of mate acquisition necessitates that we 1) determine the relative importance of various factors affecting mating, 2) assess how such effects are manifested in nature, and 3) merge theoretical predictions with empirical data to explore how well we understand the operation of mate acquisition. To accomplish these goals, the PI will use an integrative approach that employs empirical and theoretical tools to 1) assess the effects of resource availability, chance, life history, and more well studied factors on mating dynamics and 2) empirically explore the relationship between such factors and phenotypic traits that increase mating success in a range of fish species. Students will be involved in all aspects of the research and the PI will lead K-12 outreach activities. The project also involves collaborative research in Finland, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom. Funding supporting the international component was provided by the Office of International Science and Engineering.

por.por_cntn:
Overview of Outcomes

Acquiring mates is one of the most fundamental steps to successfully reproducing in many animals. Individuals vary widely in how many mates they acquire, and as a result, how many offspring they produce. Understanding why such variation exists and how it is linked to traits is essential for understanding biodiversity in general. Surprisingly, scientists are often unable to predict the conditions under which strong variation in mate acquisition will exist and which traits improve mating success. The completed research theoretically and empirically identified a range of factors that influence mate acquisition and thereby transformed our understanding of how animals successfully reproduce. The educational activities were seamlessly integrated into the project and facilitated training of K-12 students and teachers and undergraduate and graduate students.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes

The completed research enhanced our general understanding of mating dynamics through the: 1) development and analysis of mathematical models to assess the effects of resource competition, basic life history (i.e., stage-specific death and maturation rates), and chance events on mate acquisition; 2) the experimental examination of the relationship between resource availability, parental care, and mate acquisition in a fish species; and 3) synthetic reviews of how various factors interact to influence mate acquisition across animal groups. Specifically, the completed research revealed that pre-mating-pool dynamics such as resource availability and pre-adult survival can have cascading effects on subsequent mating. Similarly, the completed research revealed that chance events can in some cases influence selection on mating traits in ways that were previously unappreciated, and mating and parental care can interact to in some (but not all) cases to create reproductive barriers among populations. Our empirical research revealed that mating behavior is complex in animals and influenced by a range of factors. The completed research led to numerous (>13) peer-reviewed papers that have been or will soon by published and more than 16 regional, national, and international conference presentations. Most of these products have student co-authors. Data and code from all published projects were made publicly available.

Broader Impacts: Professional Development, Student Training, and Educational Outreach Outcomes

The research facilitated collaboration between the PI and international researchers, including Drs. Mike Bonsall (University of Oxford), Hanna Kokko (Johannes Gutenberg University Mainz), Suzanne Alonzo (University of California Santa Cruz), Leithen M’Gonigle, and Topi Lehtonen (LUKE Finland). The project also incorporated 21 undergraduate and post-bac students, six graduate students, two high-school students, one high school teacher, and two lecturers in hands-on research activities. Six of these students conducted research internationally, and several of these students presented grant-funded research at national and international conferences and are co-authors on peer-reviewed publications.  The research team also developed hands-on activities focused on evolution and animal behavior that were implemented each year (with the exception of 2020 and 2021 due to COVID-19) during a local summer camp for students from local under-resourced K-12 schools (i.e., local schools that have test scores among the lowest 5% in Tennessee). The PI also engaged high school teacher training, and one of the supported graduate students was a teacher at a local STEM school in Chattanooga. The grant facilitated the initiation of a student-focused Women in the Natural Sciences group at the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga and fostered course-based research activities with the Tennessee Aquarium.
